data.text:
Lagarde: Interest rates can rise when we see inflation reaching our 2% target over the medium term, durably and sustainably – meaning not just for a short period of time.

When these conditions are met, no one will be happier than me to normalise our monetary policy 

3/3

Lagarde: If we were to tighten monetary policy now, we would expect an impact in 18 months’ time. But our forecasts show inflation falling back by then.

We would cause unemployment and not have countered the current high inflation. I would find that wrong 

2/3

🧵 We are monitoring inflation very closely, President @Lagarde tells @faz_net editor Gerald Braunberger.

Not only because our main objective is price stability, but also because inflation affects people, especially those who are less well off https://t.co/sCvuvivg8e

1/3 https://t.co/h3YM3fR6hb

Want to know who contributed to this occasional paper? Check out the list of all the authors and contributors from the ECB and national central banks across the euro area
https://t.co/fzLtdZm2cu
3/3

The paper covers many topics, including:
1⃣The evolution and challenges of having a single central bank and multiple fiscal authorities in the euro area
2⃣The monetary and fiscal developments prompted by the coronavirus pandemic
2/3

🧵As part of our strategy review, we looked at how monetary and fiscal policy should best interact. We recently published the research that provided input for our discussions https://t.co/fzLtdZm2cu
1/3 https://t.co/eZIFgIv5IS

Ever wondered how we supervise banks? Did you know that we work closely with national authorities? Read all about European banking supervision on our redesigned website https://t.co/Qk9xVwf77Z https://t.co/DNkJdB6MgU

Want to know who contributed to this occasional paper? Check out the list of all the authors and contributors from the ECB and national central banks across the euro area
https://t.co/cCSbiIJu1F

3/3

The paper explores different legal aspects of our mandate:
➡️Our primary and secondary objectives
➡️The relevance of our mandate for financial stability
➡️The role of the instruments we use
➡️The constitutional framework within which we can operate

2/3

🧵We at the ECB must act within the competencies conferred to us by the EU Treaties. During our strategy review we explored our legal mandate to make sure to remain within our limits, and we recently published the research that informed our discussion https://t.co/cCSbiIJu1F

1/3 https://t.co/2w0u9Fqbej
Working Paper: Markups and inflation cyclicality in the euro area https://t.co/SgOKlc52xU

Want to know who contributed to this occasional paper? Check out the list of all the authors and contributors from the ECB and national central banks across the euro area
https://t.co/b2ptNE0B6l
4/4

To examine the implications for our monetary policy strategy, the paper asks two questions. 
1⃣How does globalisation affect our economic and monetary analysis?
2⃣How does it influence our monetary policy objective and instruments?
3/4

Over the years, globalisation has affected:
➡️Productivity growth
➡️The natural interest rate
➡️Inflation trends
➡️Monetary transmission
2/4

🧵Globalisation is very important to the economic environment the ECB operates in. This has implications for our monetary policy strategy. Our research looks at how globalisation and financial integration have evolved since our last strategy review https://t.co/b2ptNE0B6l
1/4 https://t.co/9P3Rgh4BLB
How did euro area bank lending and money supply evolve in October? How do they compare with September’s figures? Find out more in the press release https://t.co/zSc9PKkY9m https://t.co/MRAqhAhmI5

Independent institutions should be ready to adapt to changes in society, said President @Lagarde at the ECB Legal Conference 2021. They should interpret and apply the law in the way that best meets the needs of the people they serve https://t.co/MInaKu9vek https://t.co/2zKj4bJt60

Live now: President @Lagarde speaks at our legal conference about the tension between the role of law as a steady anchor of society and its need to adapt as the world changes. Follow it here https://t.co/LqTJA74faz https://t.co/adWElOUQGU

Coming up from 8:55 CET: day 2 of the ECB Legal Conference. 
➡️keynote speech by President Christine @Lagarde
➡️panel discussion on the relationship between law and markets
➡️panel discussion on the digitalisation of finance

Programme https://t.co/q4mPggziUs https://t.co/BpVBn68Hl8

Gender-specific violence can be inflicted on any woman. We all have a part to play in ending it. Today, to raise awareness of the issue, we lit up our buildings for the #orangetheworld initiative on the @UN International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women. https://t.co/VKJbQuHn25

The winners of this year’s #EUDatathon competition are The Carbons, @iteridea and @TrackMyEU! Congratulations to them and all the other finalists! Want to find out more about the event and the apps they created? Check out the website https://t.co/UoPkz3jdyL https://t.co/6TPaftLup8

Climate change may cause insurers to be less willing to provide cover for natural catastrophes, which would compound the impact on the economy. It is important to act quickly to make sure that losses from such events are adequately covered. Read more https://t.co/JXri9pGkxL
3/3

Insured losses from climate events have been increasing for some years and this trend looks set to continue. Following floods and wildfires in Europe in 2021, (re)insurers are facing one of their most expensive years ever in terms of natural hazards
2/3 https://t.co/HpGMM4cz5J

🧵 Climate change is a major challenge for the insurance sector. The first six months of 2021 saw the second highest level of insured losses from natural catastrophes in the past decade. We explore these developments in our Financial Stability Review https://t.co/JXri9pGkxL
1/3 https://t.co/2iROT8pc3b

Watch live from 14:30 CET: President Christine @Lagarde will introduce the keynote speech by Koen Lenaerts, President of EU Court of Justice, at this year’s legal conference. Watch it here https://t.co/0gmYMSbOOL https://t.co/2eA0s7nC5a
Working Paper: Quantitative easing and corporate innovation https://t.co/VgEAEoU5fM
Working Paper: Nowcasting euro area GDP with news sentiment - A tale of two crises https://t.co/Jj9piq1gvJ
Account of the monetary policy meeting of the Governing Council of the ECB on 27-28 October 2021 https://t.co/2a8bEH2uNi

Watch live now: Executive Board member @FrankElderson speaks at our legal conference about the relationship between climate change and the legal system, and why every EU institution should take climate change implications into account. Watch here https://t.co/t5Dmx4ROjb https://t.co/Pmn8w3rboP

Coming up from 9:00 CET: day 1 of the ECB Legal Conference. 
➡️speech by Executive Board member @FrankElderson
➡️introductory remarks by President @Lagarde
➡️keynote speech by Koen Lenaerts, President of EU Court of Justice
➡️symposium on proportionality
https://t.co/q4mPggziUs https://t.co/pnGI8o7YBo

Panetta: We should stay true to our new monetary policy strategy, using all of our instruments and retain the necessary flexibility to support the transmission of our policy stance throughout the euro area on its uncertain path out of the pandemic https://t.co/OcERRQRsGg
4/4

Panetta: We should remain focused on completing the recovery, returning GDP to its pre-crisis trend, in order to achieve self-sustained inflation at our medium-term target. If we lose patience now, we will put at risk everything we have achieved so far
3/4

Panetta: So long as short-run inflation does not destabilise inflation expectations and wage and price-setting, monetary policy should remain patient. We should not exacerbate the risk of supply shocks morphing into a demand shock and threatening the recovery
2/4

🧵The negative supply shock is hitting our economy earlier in its recovery than some other major economies, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta. This is leading to a spike in the price level, which acts as a “tax” on consumption and a brake on production
1/4 https://t.co/sOIkGYkBwi

Small and medium-sized enterprises saw improved access to external financing and are as optimistic about the future availability of financing sources as they were before the pandemic.
Read the results https://t.co/FFiwTtaUGA
3/3

Despite the recovery in business activity, small and medium-sized enterprises reported a decline in profits. This deterioration, although smaller than in previous survey rounds, reflected higher commodity prices and labour costs 
2/3

Our latest Survey on the Access to Finance of Enterprises reflects the rebound in economic activity, with small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) expecting the recovery to continue in the coming months 
1/3 https://t.co/ykK1Jeku3m

Our ultimate goal is to complete the banking union, says John Berrigan, Director-General at the @EU_Commission. There is still work to be done, but visible progress has been made. Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/INaLumk9V0 https://t.co/2JkCDSWPz4

People have become more open to buying financial services online bundled with services provided by other non-bank entities, says Supervisory Board member Pentti Hakkarainen. This exposes banks to challenges from market players, such as fintech firms https://t.co/ZmqUV0zFWW https://t.co/whgqN6LRDs

Given high uncertainty, central banks need to retain optionality to be able to respond to all contingencies. Committing policy for too long could constrain policy choices should upside risks to inflation materialise.

Read the full interview https://t.co/eXerQ9vXQb
 
2/2

🧵While rising coronavirus cases and new containment measures might dampen economic activity in the short run, they are unlikely to derail the overall recovery, Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel tells @carolynnlook and @weberalexander from Bloomberg @business
 
1/2 https://t.co/abJcdoih8U
Speech Luis de Guindos: Ralph Koijen’s contribution to research on the pricing of risk in equity and insurance markets https://t.co/dCgfXJfCui

We have approved a new oversight framework to make electronic payments safer and more efficient. It provides guidance on digital wallets, payments with crypto-assets and traditional payment instruments https://t.co/S8rXDLsbyp https://t.co/uUH89eO0VT

Last chance to register for the EU Open Data Days – don’t miss it! The event starts on Tuesday, 23 November with EU DataViz, and also features #EUDatathon, the annual EU open data competition. Register here https://t.co/hfyzqivdGz https://t.co/IwmFF5rjEj
Working paper: Credit growth, the yield curve and financial crisis prediction - evidence from a machine learning approach https://t.co/riFj6bJGYe

Have you seen our redesigned banking supervision website? 
Take a look and let us know what you think https://t.co/8ufLlMabmg
#newdesign https://t.co/Xz338xPdWb

Climate-related and environmental risks are and will remain key risk drivers for banks, writes Vice-Chair @FrankElderson in #TheSupervisionBlog. Banks must integrate them into their strategies, governance and risk management arrangements https://t.co/iAi38Jetol https://t.co/oUsX1fSEq9

The report also identifies good practices, such as new phasing-out criteria to limit financing activities that are highly exposed to climate-related risks, or assessing energy label certifications when evaluating real estate collateral 4/4

Almost all banks have developed plans to improve their practices, but the quality of these plans varies, and progress is too slow. Only one-third of banks have plans in place that are broadly adequate 3/4

Half of the banks we assessed expect to be affected by climate-related risks within the next  3-5 years. Notably, none of the banks which judged that they were not exposed had conducted a proper risk assessment 2/4

[THREAD]European banks have taken initial steps towards incorporating climate and environmental risks, but none is close to meeting all supervisory expectations. Have a look at our first report on climate-related risks in the European banking sector https://t.co/T5USr0Y1a4 1/4 https://t.co/g83n6U7Fii

Banks’ profitability has recovered to pre-pandemic levels. The challenge for them now is to finally make profitability sustainable. They need to improve their business models and cost effectiveness. 

Read about this and more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/INaLumk9V0 https://t.co/ZFsUc0UKoI

Increasing digitalisation investments in the banking sector and the shift in mindset needed for tackling climate-related risks – these are two of the key topics Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria discussed when he met staff at the Banco de Portugal this week. https://t.co/gAiFeNoH5i

We’ve given our banking supervision website a makeover! 

To help you find the information you need, we’ve also added hub pages on specific topics in all official EU languages. 

Take a look https://t.co/8ufLlMabmg https://t.co/Nnr5oXJl8h

Want to know who contributed to this occasional paper? Check out the list of all the authors and contributors from the ECB and national central banks across the euro area https://t.co/DoXloL5j8I

4/4

Our new analytical framework reflects a changing world. Looking ahead, areas that we might look at more closely are:
➡️the economic effects of climate change
➡️how our monetary policy is transmitted 
➡️changes in financial and economic structures, like the rise of non-banks

3/4

Some of the changes we have seen over time include:
➡️increased role for our projections 
➡️broader and deeper analysis of structural factors, like globalisation
➡️more focus on how our monetary policy reaches the wider economy

2/4

🧵The economic analysis, and the monetary and financial analysis compose the framework that informs our decisions. We’ve looked at how the framework has evolved and what might shape it in the future. The research fed into our strategy review https://t.co/DoXloL5j8I 
1/4 https://t.co/9ZKGCKY4Mw

Our main focus at the moment should remain on the exit from the pandemic – on the potential materialisation of credit risks when the public support measures are withdrawn, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria in the @bancodeportugal’s latest podcast episode. https://t.co/J68JDDZ5zm

Want to know who contributed to this occasional paper? Check out the list of all the authors and contributors from the ECB and national central banks across the euro area
https://t.co/Qbxm7pUBwQ 
4/4

The paper argues that monetary policy should recognise financial stability considerations and discusses some options for this, such as:
➡️being flexible about the length of the horizon for price stability
➡️expanding the analysis that feeds into monetary policy deliberations
3/4

The pursuit of financial stability through macroprudential policy can help monetary policy achieve price stability by building resilience in the financial system.
Monetary policy can also support financial stability by stabilising the economy and inflation during slowdowns
2/4

(THREAD) The importance of financial stability for the ECB’s monetary policy has increasingly gained recognition. We recently published research from our strategy review that looks at the evolution and future of this discussion https://t.co/Qbxm7pUBwQ 
1/4 https://t.co/4rfJAo5WjU
Watch again: Executive Board member Fabio Panetta on a digital euro’s positive implications for financial stability, responding to the threat of crypto-assets https://t.co/8TrRCAcd3A

Want to know who contributed to this occasional paper? Check out the list of all the authors and contributors from the ECB and national central banks across the euro area
https://t.co/MMC5MLqSfu
4/4

Non-bank finance can also be a source of volatility:
➡️non-banks’ portfolios carry more risk in the low interest rate environment
➡️problems for non-banks can spill over to other parts of the financial system
That’s why we need to make sure non-banks are properly regulated
3/4

Non-banks can affect how our monetary policy reaches the economy:
➡️they are more responsive to measures affecting long-term interest rates, like asset purchases
➡️the lack of bond market access for small firms may create differences in how our monetary policy is transmitted
2/4

(THREAD) Non-bank financial intermediation, or shadow banking, is growing as a way for firms to finance themselves. That is why it was part of our strategy review. We recently published research on the implications of this shift https://t.co/MMC5MLqSfu
1/4 https://t.co/ZzaSoxAjih
Euro area monthly balance of payments (Sept 2021) https://t.co/SDA3rHuGDt

Banks are emerging relatively unscathed from one of the worst crises on record, says Supervisory Board member Kerstin af Jochnick. To strengthen their resilience for the challenges ahead, we now need to bridge the remaining gaps in the banking union https://t.co/45IH4nbyJK https://t.co/Tp6PBaL5IO

As positive demand forces in the economy gain strength, the inflation outlook over the medium term is looking better than it did before the pandemic. We should continue nurturing these forces by not withdrawing policy support too soon https://t.co/iM9pNmtJsn 3/3

This does not mean we take this phase of higher inflation lightly. But our strategy review gave us a playbook for how to approach it. Supply shocks push up inflation and lower output. Tighter monetary policy would only worsen the contractionary effect on the economy 2/3

🧵 Inflation is largely being pushed up by exceptional pandemic circumstances, President @Lagarde says. Inflation above our 2% target has not yet become self-sustained, and for it to settle durably at our goal, we must be patient and persistent https://t.co/iM9pNmtJsn 1/3 https://t.co/2JgR1sydFr

Panetta: The challenge is different for wholesale CBDCs. They already exist: central bank money offers the safest and most liquid settlement asset for wholesale transactions to banks. But the emergence of new technologies creates new possibilities
3/3

Panetta: Central banks must evolve with payment habits and technologies. Retail CBDCs are about creating the possibility for everyone to use central bank money for digital retail payments. This is the focus of the ECB’s project to develop a digital euro
2/3

(THREAD) To preserve its role as an anchor of stability, central bank money will need to respond to evolving needs, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta. We must intensify the work on central bank digital currencies (CBDCs).
Read the blog post https://t.co/HKe6vEXC4B
1/3 https://t.co/95FTcP35kB
Watch again: Executive Board member Fabio Panetta on the importance of keeping cash available alongside a possible digital euro https://t.co/vlrqIkZwWV

Our upcoming climate stress test for banks is a learning exercise, and builds on a modular approach depending on banks’ preparedness. Read about this and more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/INaLumk9V0 https://t.co/GdXVDkUt1P

Panetta: The digital euro is about allowing everyone to use central bank money in digital form. In our investigation, we will engage with stakeholders and the public at large, including people without access to the internet or banking services https://t.co/RjbkIZpyRu
4/4

Panetta: Banks are already able to access central bank digital currency via @TARGET_ECB. The Eurosystem is working on a consolidated platform to offer enhanced and modernised services, and we are exploring possible technological improvements
3/4

Panetta: Issuing a digital euro may appear superfluous given the wide range of private digital means of payment. But private forms of money ultimately rely on the promise of convertibility into central bank money. Runs start when the confidence in convertibility disappears  
2/4

(THREAD) A digital euro would ensure that central bank money remains widely used in the digital era, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta. It would preserve the role of central bank money as an anchor of stability at the heart of the payment and financial system
1/4 https://t.co/DRJlGyj6Ia

Live now: Executive Board member Fabio Panetta reports on the investigation phase of the digital euro project to the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee of the @Europarl_EN and answers questions from its members. Watch it here https://t.co/QvRiIECIFI @EP_Economics https://t.co/j0IX3ZkiL2

Euro area investment funds recorded net inflows of €719 billion from January to September 2021, the highest amount in the last seven years for that period. This was mainly driven by funds for retail investors, with net inflows amounting to €584 billion https://t.co/0W3xFOUK1h https://t.co/83kJnuDuwb
Euro area investment fund statistics (Q3 2021) https://t.co/0W3xFOUK1h
Euro area financial vehicle corporation statistics (Q3 2021) https://t.co/Mmv6XW6wEl

Tune in at 11:00 CET to watch Executive Board member Fabio Panetta speak about the digital euro before the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee of the @Europarl_EN and answer questions from its members. Follow the webcast here https://t.co/QvRiIECIFI @EP_Economics https://t.co/O0dBknfMhO

The growth prospects for the euro area economy remain strong, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. Inflation is likely to decline next year, but monetary policy needs to retain optionality as inflation risks are increasingly skewed to the upside. https://t.co/dVDKxXOpUi https://t.co/qkMv84YeI9

How is financial stability faring as our economy rebounds from the pandemic? What has been the impact on banks, firms and households and what challenges lie on the road ahead?

Find out in our November 2021 Financial Stability Review https://t.co/WL9JClXEt6 https://t.co/drBUDdRDAc

Euro area prices are rising at the fastest pace in more than a decade. What does this have to do with droughts in Brazil, shipping containers and the pandemic? And how long will it last? Read our explainer, available in 23 EU languages https://t.co/itSoUj4QZS https://t.co/U4QfBT0Ww5

Missed this year’s Conference on Money Markets? Academics, market participants and central bankers discussed latest developments in the sector. Watch the sessions back here https://t.co/diSZZLTkPJ https://t.co/y4OiK050Bg

What does John Berrigan, Director-General at the @EU_Commission, have to say about the banking union? What is the outlook for banks’ profitability? And what does our 2022 climate stress test look like? Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/INaLumk9V0 https://t.co/FLkWnYS6gg

Corporate asset prices have soared even though the pandemic has weakened many firms. This disconnect could pose financial stability risks if investors were to become more risk averse. Read more in a preview of our Financial Stability Review https://t.co/m9qPeVzM0z https://t.co/eTt3AFnEg8

How has the pandemic affected banks? And do they have the right tools to deal with what lies ahead? 
In #TheECBPodcast, host @katieranger_ explores these questions with insights from the 2021 #ECBForum on Banking Supervision https://t.co/iH5xgONaZd https://t.co/GZoHqCz9tV
Watch again: @Lagarde on how wages are not increasing enough to sustainably push up inflation https://t.co/ENZzNv3i9y

De Guindos: Financial stability is a precondition for price stability, and vice versa. It is essential to maintain the momentum of the recovery and avoid scenarios that could put our price stability objective in jeopardy
3/3

De Guindos: Elevated corporate and sovereign debt levels, as well as stretched valuations in financial and real estate markets, are contributing to rising financial stability risks. In addressing these risks, we have to be careful not to jeopardise the still fragile recovery
2/3

(THREAD) A mix of policy measures has helped reduce near-term risks to financial stability, says Vice-President Luis de Guindos. But we see vulnerabilities increasing in the medium term https://t.co/F5KC4SEtMz
1/3 https://t.co/RoylKgC3ME

Bank mergers are often seen as a way to reduce overcapacity and weak profitability. What has driven recent bank mergers in the euro area and how have they affected profitability? Find out in a preview of our latest Financial Stability Review https://t.co/hqkscwmeiQ https://t.co/zvED3eojS5
ECB consults on its draft Guide on the notification of securitisation transactions https://t.co/Ir6Lzs3HE0
